intro: Chaerophyllum ateanum, commonly known as the Atean cow-wheat, is a flowering plant native to the Mediterranean region. It belongs to the Apiaceae family, which includes carrots and parsley, and is characterized by its umbellate inflorescence. The plant typically grows in rocky or calcareous soils and thrives in sunny to partially shaded environments. Its leaves are pinnately compound, with a rough, hairy texture, and its small white or greenish flowers appear in early spring. It is often found in open woodlands and along rocky outcrops, contributing to the biodiversity of its native habitats.
